title: academic professional seeks young scholar
text:
The lotus blossom cowers
Under the sun's bright beams;
Her forehead drooping for hours.
She waits for the night among dreams.

The Moon, he is her lover,
He wakes her with his gaze;
To him alone she uncovers
The fair flower of her face.

She glows and grows more radiant.
And gazes mutely above;
Breathing and weeping and trembling
With the piercing pain of love.

--The Lotus Blossom by Heinrich Heine

title: Wanted: a girl who loves books, coffee shops, & intelligent older men
text:
I've always imagined that the quintessential forbidden affair between a younger woman and an older man should start in a used bookstore. Better yet, a used bookstore with a coffee shop. Does such a place even exist in the District? Well, as they say, a fantasy is a story that can occur only in your imagination.

I'm a part-time college instructor. Tall, lanky, forty-something. For the sake of this fantasy, you'd have to imagine me with dark-framed glasses, thick brown hair, a white dress shirt, open at the neck, a black corduroy blazer, dark jeans, and black leather shoes. And I'd be sitting in a comfortable chair in the aforementioned bookstore/cafe with a small pot of tea on the table next to me, reading something vaguely pretentious yet impossible to put down--perhaps something on the order of Gustave Flaubert, Anais Nin, or Vladimir Nabokov.

You would come around the corner from the stacks, engrossed in page three of a book you had just found, as you made your way somewhat absentmindedly to the cafe counter where you would look up from your book only just long enough to order something hot to drink.

Of course I would have looked up from my book the moment you came around the corner, and my eyes would have followed you as you moved across the room. I would be mesmerized by your beautiful yet no-nonsense appearance: your intelligent face, your slender build, your pretty hair arranged in a simple but practical way that speaks of care but not vanity. You would be quite a bit younger than me because that's the way it always is in the classic novels; and in contrast to me, you might not have a ring on your finger. Of course you'd have to be a lifelong lover of books, bookstores, and cozy coffee shops.

Your drink now in one hand, book in the other, you would scan the room, looking for a place to sit. Your eyes would meet mine, and we would both be briefly startled by the unexpected spark in each other's eyes. You would look away, slightly flustered, and you'd quickly find a seat on the opposite side of the room.

Nothing would happen for the next minute or so, during which we would pretend to be engrossed in our respective books. But after a while, we would begin to glance up periodically whenever we thought the other wasn't looking--plausibly disinterested, yet surreptitiously examining each other from afar. Inevitably, our glances would meet again, and this time just the hint of a smile would form on our lips.

But what then? Would one of us stand up and walk over to the other, or would it end up as yet another missed connection on craigslist? That would be a shame.

title: academic professional seeks young scholar
text:
The lotus blossom cowers
Under the sun's bright beams;
Her forehead drooping for hours.
She waits for the night among dreams.

The Moon, he is her lover,
He wakes her with his gaze;
To him alone she uncovers
The fair flower of her face.

She glows and grows more radiant.
And gazes mutely above;
Breathing and weeping and trembling
With the piercing pain of love.

--The Lotus Blossom by Heinrich Heine

There are few things in life more delightful than pinning a lover's arms above her head while softly whispering her favorite poetry into her ear.

title: Wanted: a girl who loves books, coffee shops, & intelligent older men
text:
I've always imagined that the quintessential forbidden affair between a younger woman and an older man should start in a used bookstore. Better yet, a used bookstore with a coffee shop. Does such a place even exist in the District? Well, as they say, a fantasy is a story that can occur only in your imagination.

I'm a part-time college instructor. Tall, lanky, forty-something. For the sake of this fantasy, you'd have to imagine me with dark-framed glasses, thick brown hair, a white dress shirt, open at the neck, a black corduroy blazer, dark jeans, and black leather shoes. And I'd be sitting in a comfortable chair in the aforementioned bookstore/cafe with a small pot of tea on the table next to me, reading something vaguely pretentious yet impossible to put down--perhaps something on the order of Gustave Flaubert, Anais Nin, or Vladimir Nabokov.

You would come around the corner from the stacks, engrossed in page three of a book you had just found, as you made your way somewhat absentmindedly to the cafe counter where you would look up from your book only just long enough to order something hot to drink.

Of course I would have looked up from my book the moment you came around the corner, and my eyes would have followed you as you moved across the room. I would be mesmerized by your beautiful yet no-nonsense appearance: your intelligent face, your slender build, your pretty hair arranged in a simple but practical way that speaks of care but not vanity. You would be quite a bit younger than me because that's the way it always is in the classic novels; and in contrast to me, you might not have a ring on your finger. Of course you'd have to be a lifelong lover of books, bookstores, and cozy coffee shops.

Your drink now in one hand, book in the other, you would scan the room, looking for a place to sit. Your eyes would meet mine, and we would both be briefly startled by the unexpected spark in each other's eyes. You would look away, slightly flustered, and you'd quickly find a seat on the opposite side of the room.

Nothing would happen for the next minute or so, during which we would pretend to be engrossed in our respective books. But after a while, we would begin to glance up periodically whenever we thought the other wasn't looking--plausibly disinterested, yet surreptitiously examining each other from afar. Inevitably, our glances would meet again, and this time just the hint of a smile would form on our lips.

But what then? Would one of us stand up and walk over to the other, or would it end up as yet another missed connection on craigslist? That would be a shame.

If you have an idea of where you'd like this story to lead, send me your thoughts. Doing so will help me separate you from the spam and will also make it easier for me to gauge your level of interest and sincerity. I will respond to any thoughtful reply that I receive.

As for the sort of woman I am seeking: You don't necessarily need to be in the extremely high IQ range, or have advanced degrees, yourself. You do, however, need to have good sense, value knowledge, and have a desire to continue to learn and explore both mentally and physically. title: Confident, Experienced, Knowledgeable, Funny and Enjoyable
text:
First, let me say thank you for opening this personal ad and taking the time to read through it. Craigslist is an interesting place to post a personal ad. 

A little about me. . .. 
In order to describe me, I think it is best to say what friends would say about me, these are their words that would describe this guy as "Confident, Intuitive, Experienced (old soul type of guy), Knowledgeable, Funny and Enjoyable." Each of these words describe me to a T and I am sure that after you take the time to hold a conversation, you will come to the same conclusion. 

I am the guy that is a good and trusted friend, enjoys to share in most every way that is possible, enjoys short and long trips both around the local area as well as across the country and internationally. I have been to Germany, Austria, Panama, and Venezuela across 20 years. Before I go to a new place for anything, I like to take the time to research, read and see what others have found interesting with regards to the people (yes, the locals), the area, the food, and the history. Also, many of the reviews can provide insight into what there is to do there, enjoy and where to sample the local cuisine. 

I work full time at a job that I enjoy, feel I am making a difference, and know that when I leave at the end of each day -- there is a difference made. But when I am not working -- such on the weekends and holidays, I am always looking and seeking out what is happening in the area where I am. There is just really too much to do in the course of a weekend or holiday. My type of movie is more of one that can captivate my attention and totally draws me in and keeps me there until it is over.

About the one I'm looking for. . .. 
I am looking for a guy that is as gregarious, confident, and enjoyable as I am. I would like for him to be as engaged with his work as I am, but knows that the work and home life are separate, but do cross at times. I want him to have his autonomy and know how his life experiences can be blended with mine and can see where there are compatibilities, alignment, and enhancements with all these being surrounded by enrichment. I am not searching, looking, wanting or desiring for the guy to be carbon copy (yes, a very aged word) of me -- blending, being together, talking on most any topic will expand and provide the foundation for the future. So, I want to be able to use these words for the guy that I am looking for -- a friend, a bud, a confidant, a soul mate, my other half, and above all a very close companion.

So, if you have read this far -- here are some other aspects that I feel are important to know about -- I am divorced, I am a daily smoker, my sign is Libra with a Scorpio rising; my body is average; my eyes are blue; I grew up in Richmond, Virginia; I have a grown son; my ethnicity is white (Caucasian); my height is five feet ten inches; and my hair is brown with gray, more gray than brown.

About my personality type. . .. 
I can cook, but don't find that to be my forte; I am a patient man; I am quite the romantic; I am punctuational as I am either early or right on time; and I enjoy movies, live theatre and getting off the well worn path.

As far as getting to know, I would say that I am the guy that will do the emails and exchanges, but then would much rather talk on the phone and in person over coffee, dinner, or just a day's outing -- I want to get to know the other guy as I want him to get to know me and this is better in person and not using the "words on the screen." 

So with all the above, you have good demographic portrait and I hope that it has created a spark of interest to take that first step and respond.

All the best to you if you got to this sentence!

title: Professor Seeks Bookworm
text:
It's almost 9pm on a Saturday night and there's nothing to do. Most of the other twenty-somethings and thirty-somethings are going out to the bars and clubs. You could go too; perhaps your friends have invited you to go out with them; but it's really not your thing. What you wish most of all was that the library was open. A really nice library, with cozy chairs, hardwood floors, area rugs, and real wooden bookshelves. But at this time of night, all of the libraries are closed and locked. Apparently nobody likes to read a Saturday night.

Still, you like to fantasize. You like to imagine yourself walking through the aisles, pausing ever so briefly each time one of your familiar favorites catches your eye: Austen, Bronte, Dickens, Dickinson, Faulkner, Hemingway, Hugo, Joyce. . . Just seeing the names brings a smile to your face as you recall the pleasures that their words have given you over the years. You've already read almost everything by the great ones, but there is always something more. Another treat to savor. Those last few Shakespeare plays you've never read. Or one of Vladimir Nabokov's more obscure novels from his Russian period. Or Finnegans Wake. No, not Finnegans Wake. You need something that will satisfy tonight, not next year. How about an Emily Dickinson poem? Yes.

You pull a book off the shelf, open to a random page, and continue slowly walking down the aisle as you read the words

Master--open
your life wide, and
take me in forever,
I will never be tired--
I will never be noisy
when you want to be
still--I will be
your best little
girl--

Suddenly, not looking where you are going, you walk right smack into a man. A tall man in a corduroy blazer and dark rimmed glasses. A man who is probably at least ten years older than you, if not more. A man who is surprisingly fit and attractive in a college professor sort of way. Where did he come from? This is your library. Your dream. Your imagination. You thought you were alone. Embarrassed and flustered, you apologize and quickly turn around to head in the other direction.

"The library is closed. What are you doing here? How did you get in here?" His voice is deep and smooth. Strong. And as he speaks, he places a firm hand on your shoulder.

"What are you reading?" he asks as he steps closer and places his other hand on your other shoulder. You wonder what kind of dream this is. You can feel his eyes as they read the words on the page

nobody else will see me, but you--
but that is enough--
I shall not want any more--

His big hands begin to slide down your arms, and you can feel your breath quickening. You notice a simple gold band on his finger, and your eyes fixate on it as he takes the book from you, closes it, and places it on the shelf.

You turn around to face him, and you raise your head until the two of you are looking directly into each other's eyes. An academic man and a young scholar. A common love for literature. A quiet place to share each other's interests.

Perhaps we should continue the discussion in a real library?

title: Wanted: a girl who loves books, coffee shops, & intelligent older men
text:
I've always imagined that the quintessential forbidden affair between a younger woman and an older man should start in a used bookstore. Better yet, a used bookstore with a coffee shop. Does such a place even exist in the District? Well, as they say, a fantasy is a story that can occur only in your imagination.

I'm a part-time college instructor. Tall, lanky, forty-something. For the sake of this fantasy, you'd have to imagine me with dark-framed glasses, thick brown hair, a white dress shirt, open at the neck, a black corduroy blazer, dark jeans, and black leather shoes. And I'd be sitting in a comfortable chair in the aforementioned bookstore/cafe with a small pot of tea on the table next to me, reading something vaguely pretentious yet impossible to put down--perhaps something on the order of Gustave Flaubert, Anais Nin, or Vladimir Nabokov.

You would come around the corner from the stacks, engrossed in page three of a book you had just found, as you made your way somewhat absentmindedly to the cafe counter where you would look up from your book only just long enough to order something hot to drink.

Of course I would have looked up from my book the moment you came around the corner, and my eyes would have followed you as you moved across the room. I would be mesmerized by your beautiful yet no-nonsense appearance: your intelligent face, your slender build, your pretty hair arranged in a simple but practical way that speaks of care but not vanity. You would be quite a bit younger than me because that's the way it always is in the classic novels; and in contrast to me, you might not have a ring on your finger. Of course you'd have to be a lifelong lover of books, bookstores, and cozy coffee shops.

Your drink now in one hand, book in the other, you would scan the room, looking for a place to sit. Your eyes would meet mine, and we would both be briefly startled by the unexpected spark in each other's eyes. You would look away, slightly flustered, and you'd quickly find a seat on the opposite side of the room.

Nothing would happen for the next minute or so, during which we would pretend to be engrossed in our respective books. But after a while, we would begin to glance up periodically whenever we thought the other wasn't looking--plausibly disinterested, yet surreptitiously examining each other from afar. Inevitably, our glances would meet again, and this time just the hint of a smile would form on our lips.

But what then? Would one of us stand up and walk over to the other, or would it end up as yet another missed connection on craigslist? That would be a shame.

If you have an idea of where you'd like this story to lead, send me your thoughts. Doing so will help me separate you from the spam and will also make it easier for me to gauge your level of interest and sincerity. I will respond to any thoughtful reply that I receive.
